fields.summary: Load balancer instance times out when getting metadata

fields.description:
I had ab running against multicluster ELB setup for a week. I periodically checked in and things were more or less behaving.  However today I decided to stop this exercise and move on to some other testing on the system when I found out that service calls more often than not timed out and CPU usage hovering in the 100%-120% range.

example timeout
{code}
[root@c-07 ~]# euca-describe-instances verbose
euca-describe-instances: error: HTTPConnectionPool(host='10.111.1.42', port=8773): Request timed out. (timeout=10)
{code}

[~kedwards] has taken a look and found that there are some thread locks and that the servo vm is toast. He has some thread dumps and will be adding them to this bug.

[~decker] will be bumping up heap size for euca

[~spark] will likely take a hack at the servo part too.

Topology:
 \[UI CLC WS SC00 CC00\]
 \[SC01 CC01\]
 \[NC00\]
 \[NC01\]
fields.summary: Deadlock, dead servo vm and how I killed ELB

comments.body: [~kedwards] has tracked this down and its possibly netty.

it appears that actually the problem is triggered by servo VM.
I think there are two issues:

-- somehow boto in the servo doesn't refresh IAM role credentials. so the service side fails to authenticate.
-- when the message stack fails to authenticate repeatedly, Netty seems to take all the memory and cause the whole system out of memory.

I think the first issue can be resolved quickly (still need to figure out why), but the second issue needs investigation as well (cause DOS attach is quite possible with it).

On the servo VM, the issue was that boto used 1 sec as timeout when it refresh IAM credentials. 
when boto retrieves, it navigates down the metadata path to get credentials and if timeout ever happens during the navigation, it could't refresh the credential.

So here's the possible scenario
1) service operated well
2) there was glitch and servo vm failed to get the credential
3) servo vm hits the service with old credentials
4) clc fails to authenticate and system becomes slow 
5) servo vm continue to fail to refresh the credential
6) now the system went into thrashing state

The quick fix on the servo VM side is to change the boto timeout to larger value.

The servo VM should have this config in /etc/boto.cfg 

\[Boto\]
metadata_service_timeout = 10

I'll put the boto configuration file under /etc/load-balancer-servo/ and use BOTO_CONFIG environment variable to point at that location. Setting the location of the file will be available as a command line option to the service daemon itself.

I setup a fresh 3.3 cloud yesterday afternoon (May 21) I've been running a for loop of describe images in 2 separate processes each with different invalid credentials for over 17 hours and the system has not locked up as of yet. Either this test is not correct for reproducing the issue or the root cause may be elsewhere.
Yeah, the failure to authenticate may be the outcome of the bug and the root cause is else where. I'm looking at another one..

after the conversation w/ [~sjones] and [~tony], I think it's very likely that the same Netty memory leak caused this problem.
-- Tony ran 'ab' continuously for over 5 days
-- ELB reported the cloudwatch metrics to cloudwatch service via internal message
-- [~tony] saw it works fine until 5th day during which the leak built up
-- At 7th day or so, Netty exploded.

when [~sjones] pushes the patch to testing, I'll merge it to the branch where ELB reports CW metric at much finer interval to the CW service (currently 1 min -> 5-10 seconds). If running 'ab' against the ELB doesn't cause the problem, I think we should be fine.
[~spark], the fix for the resource leak when sending internal messages is now in testing.
downgraded priority as we have verified so far in manual tests that this is resolved.
i've run 'ab' against the elb which reports CW metrics every 10 seconds (1 minute is normal). The test have been running 4 days and the system is ok.

Fix Verified.

The issue has yet to be reproduced by an means since fixes were delivered. This issue is considered fix.
